V.iii.2.B.4.a
.
Definitions: Dizziness, Vertigo, Pre-syncope, and Disequilibrium
Dizziness
is a sensation or perception of unsteadiness, imbalance, or potential unconsciousness.
Vertigo
is a sensation of rotation or spinning movement – either the self or surrounding objects – when there is no actual movement.  Vertigo is best understood as a variety of dizziness where the feeling of unsteadiness or imbalance is due to the sense of spinning.
Presyncope
is a feeling of losing consciousness or blacking out.  The terms
lightheadness
and
faintness
are essentially synonymous although lightheadedness may also be used to describe a feeling of disconnectedness between the head and body rather than actual impending unconsciousness.
Disequilibrium
means loss of equilibrium (balance, stability, physical orientation).  A disability causing disequilibrium is manifested by symptoms that fall under the umbrella of dizziness (including vertigo or presyncope).
